title: 109_hr409
content: The Act titled "Sierra National Forest Land Exchange Act of 2006" defines key terms such as Council, Federal land, non-Federal land, Project No. 67, and Secretary. The Secretary of Agriculture is defined as the Secretary in the Sierra National Forest Land Exchange Act of 2006. The Act authorizes a land exchange in California, where the owner of non-Federal land can convey it to the United States in exchange for Federal land and a cash payment. The Secretary can make corrections to legal descriptions in consultation with the landowner. The Secretary and the owner of the non-Federal land may agree to make corrections and minor modifications to legal descriptions, with a limit on affecting the exchange value. The non-Federal land is valued at $200,000, and the Federal land at $250,000. Upon acquisition, the Secretary will manage the non-Federal land according to the Weeks Act. The Secretary will convey Federal land subject to conditions including the recipient conveying all 160 acres to the Council within 120 days, granting an easement to Project No. 67, and giving the owner of Project No. 67 the right of first refusal for any reconveyance. Cash equalization funds received will be deposited by the Secretary. The Secretary will deposit equalization payment funds received under Public Law 90-171 in a fund for land acquisition in California. The owner of non-Federal land must pay all direct costs for processing the land exchange, which will be deposited in a cost collection account for the Secretary's use. The Secretary will use funds for land exchange costs without further appropriation. Any remaining amounts in the cost collection account will be refunded to the owner of non-Federal land. The Sierra National Forest boundaries as of January 1, 1965, will apply for the Land and Water Conservation Fund. A grant of easement and right of first refusal was agreed upon by the Forest Service, the Council, and the owner of Project No. 67 in 2006. The Secretary will grant an easement and a right of first refusal to the owner of Project No. 67. The Secretary must ensure that the public interest is served when exercising discretion. An amendment to the Energy Policy Act of 2005 allocates funds to improve the commercial value of forest biomass for various purposes.
